g.text: aerosol forcing, but the albedo modi
cation enforces a land surface cooling that is
consistent with that of the Pinatubo coupled model experiment. This strategy has
the advantage of allowing surface land temperature to vary in the presence of SST
anomalies (in the OCEAN experiment), as is seen in other model experiments in
the context of global warming scenario
. This is hence more physically relevant
than experiments that constrain land surface temperature
unphysical and exaggerated land cooling, and hence exaggerated land
gradients. We modify the land surface albedo to restore the atmospheric
temperatures over land to that of the Control coupled model ensemble in ATM and
to that of the Pinatubo coupled model ensemble in LAND.
in response to a given change in
at the surface can be approximated
being the feedback parameter including that due to the Planck emission
(i.e., the feedback associated with changes in surface temperature), changes in
vertical temperature lapse rate, water vapour and clouds. Here, we specify
. The surface albedo is related to the
Here, the subscript c denotes the values of the control coupled model experiment,
while the subscript p designates the values of the Pinatubo coupled model
, the relative change of the incoming SW
radiation due to stratospheric sulphate aerosols:

), but we modify the surface albedo to

). Using previous relationships together with (2) and (4),
Conversely, in LAND, the surface albedo is set to the
downward shortwave radiation equal to the control experiments
), but surface-absorbed shortwave equal to that of
from the control and Pinatubo mean ensemble simulations
and performed ATM and LAND simulations imposing the albedo in order to
restore the surface temperature towards control and Pinatubo values respectively.
This protocol involves a linearity assumption of assumed constant values for the
. Surface temperature anomalies in the ATM, LAND and
OCEAN experiments (Fig. 4 and Supplementary Fig. 10) however add up quite
linearly to surface temperature anomalies in the ALL atmospheric or Pinatubo
coupled model experiment, indicating the validity of our approach. The LAND
experiment isolates the effect of volcanically induced continental cooling but does
not narrow down the region that plays a key role for inducing wind anomalies over
c. We hence also developed a suite of additional 30-member
LAND sensitivity experiments (with and without Pinatubo radiative forcing) that
allows exploring the respective roles of land cooling in the tropics (LAND-T), the
and the maritime continent (LAND-MC) only (See Supplementary Table 2).
the wind changes over the Paci
c associated with three different processes: direct
effect of radiative forcing on the atmosphere (ATM) and indirect effect through the
cooling of continents (LAND) and induced oceanic SST gradients (OCEAN). To
translate those wind signals into SST responses, we use a linear continuously
c region combined with a linear
SST equation. The LCS model is forced by the atmospheric forcing produced by
each of the 30-member experiments above to deduce the equatorial Paci
response (and in particular the SST response). The LCS model for the Indo-Paci
Ocean resolves vertical baroclinic modes. It is used to simulate thermocline depth
and near-surface current anomalies. It is combined with a linear SST equation
realistically resolve the variations of SST due to wind stress anomalies:
The horizontal advection term is approximated from the anomalous advection
) gradient (here from the IPSL historical run
c region, zonal advection dominates over meridional advection (not
shown, see for example Vialard et al.
from the sea surface height anomaly
parameterizes the vertical physics, i.e., the interannual modulation of mixing and
upwelling by thermocline depth anomalies. The coef
its maximum value at the western boundary of the Paci
c, as in McGregor et al.
This mimics the decreasing effect of the upwelling as the climatological
thermocline deepens towards the west. Heat
2 months, close to values used by McGregor et al.
baroclinic modes are used (even though mainly only the
. This model has the advantage of being relatively realistic (Validation:
0.9 with observations (TAO, AVISO, OSCAR), notably for
zonal current and SST in Niño4 (central Paci
modes are important, and also for SST and SSH in Niño3 (eastern Paci
the model is forced by ERAI (see details in Izumo et al.
and cheap to use. It is used to simulate the SST response to wind stress anomalies
diagnosed from the ATM, LAND and OCEAN AGCM ensemble members. The
high correlation of the IPSL-CM5B coupled model Niño3.4 SST anomalies with
those simulated by the LCS model forced by the coupled model experiments
es our approach. Furthermore, the favourable comparison of the ALL
ensemble mean with the coupled model experiment wind stress anomalies in the
c region (Supplementary Fig. 10) lends credence to
our method and suggests that our two-tier methodology to investigate various
physical mechanisms in forced experiments derived from the coupled one is sound.
. For the analysis of these Pinatubo sensitivity
experiments, we used two approaches to evaluate the statistical signi
anomalies associated with volcanic forcing, relative to purely random, internal
atmosphere variability. The anomalies associated with the response
to volcanism are computed as paired differences between each of the members
of the Pinatubo experiment and its unforced counterpart. The
cance of the anomaly between the two
ensemble means using a two-tailed Welch
-test, and taking into account the size
and variance of each (control and Pinatubo) ensemble. For CMIP5 model analyses,
cance of anomalies relative to the climatology is measured using a
-test, considering each model as an independent degree of
freedom. For both our paired Pinatubo ensembles and CMIP5 models, we also
estimated at each time step and grid point the percentage for which at least two
thirds of the individual simulations have anomalies of consistent sign, which is a
commonly used technique for analysing outputs of CMIP models. This allows us to
cant anomalies in the ensemble mean are repre-
sentative of the ensemble members and not due to a few extreme members. Figure
captions specify the test for each
. The code and data that support the
study are available from the corresponding authors on request.

real-time seasonal ENSO model predictions during 2002

c and their relationship to El Niño and La Niña.
5. Collins, M. et al. The impact of global warming on the tropical Paci

uence of volcanic eruptions on the climate of the
